question: Question_12_(b)
statement:
Consider the plane \emph{x - y + z = 0}.

\textbf{b)} Let \textbf{u} =
$\left[\begin{array}{c} 1 \\ 1 \\ 1\end{array}\right]$. Find vectors
\textbf{v} and \textbf{w} such that \textbf{u} = \textbf{v} +
\textbf{w}, where \textbf{v} is in the plane and \textbf{w} is
perpendicular to the plane.
sols:
If we apply the projection of
\href{Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH221/April_2013/Question_12_(a)}{(a)}
to the vector \textbf{\emph{u}}, we get a vector \textbf{\emph{w}} that
is orthogonal to the plane. To get \textbf{\emph{v}}, we simply subtract
\textbf{\emph{w}} from \textbf{\emph{u}}.

To verify that \textbf{\emph{v}} is indeed on the plane, we compute
that\begin{align*}P_1(v) = P_1(u - w) = P_1(u) - P_1(w) = w - w = 0,\end{align*} which shows
that the vector \textbf{\emph{v}} has no competent that is orthogonal to
the plane. Thus \textbf{\emph{v}} must lie in the plane itself.

Let's perform the necessary calculations to get \textbf{\emph{w}} and
\textbf{\emph{v}}. We have

\begin{align*}w = \frac{u \cdot \left[ \begin{array}{ccc} 1 & -1 & 1  \\  \end{array} \right]} {3} \left[ \begin{array}{ccc} 1 & -1 & 1  \\  \end{array} \right] = \frac{1}{3} \left[ \begin{array}{ccc} 1 & -1 & 1  \\  \end{array} \right]\end{align*}

And hence
$v = u - w = \left[ \begin{array}{ccc} \frac{2}{3} & \frac{4}{3} & \frac{2}{3}  \\  \end{array} \right]$.

'\textbf{'Note}: It is also easy to directly verify that
\textbf{\emph{v}} satisfies the equation \emph{x - y + z = 0} of the
plane, since $2/3 -4/3 + 2/3 = 0$.
